file_metadata.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian
file_metadata.title: Charging Ahead: Examining the Future Therapeutic Potential of Electroceuticals

chunks.text: Electroceuticals, derived from "electronic" and "pharmaceuticals," aim to therapeutically manipulate neuronal signaling. This field has expanded significantly, leading to a need for a revised framework that goes beyond neuron-targeted interventions. This review proposes a broader definition of electroceuticals, encompassing interventions targeting electrical signals in any cell type, not just neurons, and suggests categorizing them based on the physiological level of action: cellular, tissue, organ, and systemic. The review discusses emerging developments and future directions for each category, highlighting challenges like the lack of clinical biomarkers and incomplete understanding of mechanisms of action, and offers solutions to accelerate progress in this field.
chunks.chunk_summary: A revised framework for electroceuticals is proposed, broadening the scope beyond neuron-targeted interventions to encompass any cell type and categorizing them by physiological level of action.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Electroceuticals, initially defined as the manipulation of neuronal signaling using devices for therapeutic effect, have evolved significantly. The nervous system's role in regulating bodily processes makes its modulation via electroceuticals promising for treating various diseases. Recent research in developmental bioelectricity has expanded the understanding of ion-driven electrical communication beyond neurons to other cell types, opening possibilities for intervention in areas like birth defects, cancer, and metabolic diseases. Despite the therapeutic potential, pharmaceutical companies have limitedly explored electroceuticals. This review proposes a revised ontology and framework for electroceuticals, incorporating recent bioelectricity research, to bring greater coherence and inclusivity to the field and encourage collaboration among stakeholders.
chunks.chunk_summary: Electroceuticals have evolved beyond neuronal manipulation, and a revised framework incorporating bioelectricity research is proposed to broaden the field and encourage collaboration.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: The field of electroceuticals has expanded beyond established interventions like pacemakers and cochlear implants. Research on the vagal inflammatory reflex demonstrated the neural control of the immune system, leading to targeted electrical therapies like Barostim and SetPoint medical's implant.  A revised ontology for electroceuticals is proposed to address the ambiguous terminology and the limited focus on neuron-targeted devices. This new ontology aims to encompass the broader applications of electrical signaling in various cell types and incorporate new techniques like optogenetics. A clearer framework with consistent terminology will facilitate understanding and accelerate progress in the field.
chunks.section: Electroceuticals: The Need for a Revised Ontology and Framework
chunks.chunk_summary: A revised ontology for electroceuticals is needed to clarify terminology, broaden the scope beyond neuron-targeted devices, and incorporate new techniques like optogenetics.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: A revised definition of electroceuticals is proposed: the use of a therapeutic intervention to treat or prevent disease through the alteration of electrical signals in any cell type. This definition includes drugs, devices, and future modalities, covering a range of therapeutic benefits. The targets are broadened to include excitable and nonexcitable cells, and "alteration" encompasses various modifications achieved through manipulating inherent signals or introducing external stimuli. A potential ontology for bioelectric research is suggested, categorized by physiological level: cellular, tissue, organ, and systemic.  Nondevice-driven approaches are termed "bioelectroceuticals," while exogenous electric stimuli via devices are termed "bioelectronic medicine" or BEM.
chunks.chunk_summary: Electroceuticals are redefined as any therapeutic intervention altering electrical signals in any cell type, categorized by physiological level of action.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Cellular level bioelectric signaling involves inter- and intracellular electrical signaling mediated by changes in resting membrane potential (Vmem). Ion channels transduce bioelectrical signals into secondary messenger responses, affecting cell behavior. Organelle-level bioelectric signaling, a nascent research area, involves signaling cascades essential for organelle homeostasis.  Alternating electric fields can degrade protein aggregates in Alzheimer's disease and trigger apoptosis in cancer cells. Applications of cellular level bioelectric signaling include embryogenesis, metabolism, and cancer.
chunks.chunk_summary: Cellular bioelectric signaling, mediated by changes in Vmem, influences cell behavior and has applications in various areas including cancer and stem cell research.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Cellular level bioelectric signaling plays a role in stem cell behavior and cancer. In stem cells, endogenous electrical signaling influences proliferation and differentiation. Exogenous electrical stimulation (EStim) can also affect stem cell fate in vitro and in vivo, offering a novel way to control stem cell behavior for regenerative medicine. In cancer, changes in Vmem are associated with increased proliferation, invasion, and metastasis. Cancer cells exhibit depolarized Vmem compared to normal cells. Manipulating bioelectric properties, such as through ion channel modulators, can influence tumor incidence and drive cancer cells towards differentiation and senescence. The "Celex hypothesis" suggests that electrical excitability contributes to cancer metastasis.
chunks.topic: Cellular Bioelectricity in Stem Cells and Cancer
chunks.chunk_summary: Cellular bioelectric signaling influences stem cell fate and cancer progression, with Vmem changes playing a key role in both.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Challenges in translating cellular level bioelectric signaling to the clinic include incomplete biological understanding of the mechanisms, lack of high-throughput screens and relevant models, and difficulty in selectively modulating bioelectricity for therapeutic effect.  Questions remain about how bioelectricity influences different cell types, the involved genes and pathways, and the cell-specific and disease-specific variations. Patch clamp is the gold standard for measuring Vmem, but it is low throughput.  Developing new methods for studying cellular bioelectroceuticals and screening compounds that alter Vmem is crucial.  Computational tools like machine learning and bioelectric simulators are being used for predictive control of bioelectric states.
chunks.chunk_summary: Translating cellular bioelectricity to the clinic faces challenges in understanding mechanisms, developing high-throughput screens, and achieving targeted modulation.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Tissue-level bioelectric signaling involves inherent electrical signals that vary depending on the tissue's state (development, injury, disease, or health). External electrical stimuli can alter development and healing. Applications include wound healing, where an endogenous electrical field guides cell migration (electrotaxis); tumor tissue treatment, where tumor-treating electrical fields (TTFields) disrupt cancer cell proliferation and stimulate apoptosis; and engineered tissue, where electrical stimulation improves tissue organization and function, particularly in cardiac and bone tissue engineering.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tissue-level bioelectric signaling plays a role in wound healing, tumor treatment, and engineered tissue development.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: In wound healing, an endogenous electrical field guides cell migration into the wound (electrotaxis). Vomaris's Procellera dressing generates microcurrents similar to the skin's physiological electric field, promoting wound healing and antimicrobial effects. In tumor treatment, TTFields, low-intensity alternating electric fields, disrupt cancer cell proliferation and stimulate apoptosis by interfering with mitotic spindle formation and cytokinesis. Novocure's Optune and Optune Lua are FDA-approved TTFields therapies for certain cancers. In engineered tissue, electrical stimulation improves tissue organization and function, as demonstrated in cardiac and bone tissue engineering using EStim, MStim, and piezoelectric biomaterials.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tissue bioelectricity applications include wound healing with electrotaxis, tumor treatment with TTFields, and engineered tissue development with electrical stimulation.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Despite promising clinical data for Procellera and Optune, further independent research is needed for wider adoption. Clinical readouts from TTFields/PD-1 combination trials are anticipated.  Optimizing EStim requires a better understanding of cellular responses and standardization of therapeutic protocols and devices.
chunks.chunk_summary: Challenges in tissue bioelectricity include the need for more independent research, standardized protocols, and a deeper understanding of cellular responses to EStim.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Organ-level bioelectric signaling involves electrical communication through peripheral nerves connecting organs to the central nervous system and other organs. Organ-level bioelectronic medicine (BEM) addresses dysfunction in this signaling using electronic devices. BEMs can be classified as "broad" or "precise" based on their specificity. Broad BEMs deliver non-targeted electrical pulses to manage symptoms in chronic conditions like pain and tremor. Examples include TENS, SCS, and DBS. Precise BEMs deliver targeted electrical pulses to trigger specific biological mechanisms, such as modulating the inflammatory reflex to treat autoimmune diseases or stimulating cardiovascular reflexes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Organ-level BEMs address dysfunction in electrical signaling through peripheral nerves, classified as "broad" or "precise" based on their targeting specificity.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Broad BEMs, like TENS, SCS, and DBS, deliver non-targeted electrical pulses to manage symptoms, often with unknown mechanisms of action.  Cutting-edge developments include closed-loop therapies and applications to new diseases.  Precise BEMs deliver targeted pulses to trigger specific mechanisms, like modulating the inflammatory reflex.  Examples include SetPoint Medical's studies in RA and Crohn's disease and Galvani's study in RA. Precise BEMs also stimulate cardiovascular reflexes for hypertension and heart failure. Innovations include improved device form and function, sense-and-respond mechanisms, and new disease targets.
chunks.chunk_summary: Broad BEMs offer non-targeted symptom management, while precise BEMs target specific mechanisms, with ongoing innovations in both areas.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Challenges for organ-level BEMs include incomplete understanding of disease biology and mechanisms of action, evidence requirements and controls in clinical trials, and distinguishing therapeutic effects from safety concerns.  Understanding neural control of diseases is crucial for effective targeting.  A more detailed understanding of MoA is needed for target validation.  Clinical trials need rigorous controls to determine true treatment effects.  Variations in patient responses and stimulation parameters require careful assessment for safety and efficacy.  Key questions involve treatment effect size, predictive biomarkers, parameter optimization, and potential for tachyphylaxis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Organ-level BEMs face challenges in understanding disease biology and MoA, designing rigorous clinical trials, and optimizing treatment parameters for safety and efficacy.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Systems-level bioelectric signaling involves voltage gradients that specify information like axial polarity, patterning, and organ identity, playing a vital role in development, remodeling, and regeneration. A morphogenetic code, including bioelectricity, regulates large-scale changes by controlling gene expression and cell behaviors. Studies in planaria and Xenopus demonstrate the ability to manipulate bioelectric patterns to alter regeneration and induce eye formation in non-competent tissues. Bioelectric properties also regulate tissue scaling and size. Exogenous EStim can improve regeneration, particularly in nerves.  Bioelectric signaling differs from traditional ion channel biology in that it focuses on spatial voltage gradients rather than individual ion channels.
chunks.chunk_summary: Systems-level bioelectric signaling, a component of the morphogenetic code, regulates large-scale changes in development and regeneration through spatial voltage gradients.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Cracking the bioelectric code at the systems level has immense potential in developmental and regenerative biology. However, this is a nascent area of research explored by a limited number of academics. We do not fully understand how bioelectric signals are established and maintained, how they encode information for large-scale patterning, and how to rewrite these signals to achieve desired outcomes.  Further research is needed to translate these findings into therapeutic applications.
chunks.chunk_summary: The main challenge in systems-level bioelectricity is the limited understanding of how bioelectric signals are established, maintained, and rewritten for therapeutic applications.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian

chunks.text: Progress in electroceuticals requires collaboration across the life science ecosystem.  The future of electroceuticals holds promise for disease treatment, tissue and organ regeneration, and even alleviating aging effects.  Commercial viability depends on selecting diseases with high unmet need, demonstrating improved efficacy and safety, maintaining patient convenience, securing patent life, ensuring scalability, and addressing pricing and reimbursement.  Realizing this vision requires a better understanding of bioelectricity's rules and information encoding at various physiological levels.  Collaboration is crucial to deconvolute the molecular mechanisms of electroceuticals.
chunks.chunk_summary: Collaboration is crucial for advancing electroceuticals, which hold promise for various applications, but commercial success depends on addressing several factors including unmet needs, efficacy, and market access.
chunks.authors: Swarnalatha Balasubramanian, David A. Weston, Michael Levin, Devon Charles Cardoso Davidian
